If you compiled them into deb packages it will show them.
There is no real way to get a comprehensive list of stuff you have installed by compiling with something like make install where it puts them directly into the filesystem

One of the points of having a packaging system is to be able to track what's installed. when you do make install or such it bypasses the package manager's ability to track it.
- true but many apps are not available in the repos so onemost install other ways ya know

If you look in the file ~/.bash_history it will have a record of commands you have recently typed in. You may find at least some of them there if you find something like: cd prog-name   then: make and: make install      etc
Otherwise it is up to you to keep good records of what you manually install
